Dear Adriene,
As a beginner, I felt anxious to follow quick flows which I used to have in yoga classes last year. I love yoga, but somehow I felt I had been progressing slowly. There was the point when I pushed myself with classes, and I ended up having a mild meniscus tear. It was a heartbreaking moment. After three months therapy, my therapist encouraged me to get back to gentle yoga. She said I was ready, but I did not dare to.
Quarantine let us stay more at home and become even less active. That time I knew my body and mind needed balance. I started yoga again after 8 months of giving up. I found this Yoga Kiss. As a yoga teacher, you did not sound to push or force us and that was what I told myself to just enjoy and go with the flow.
After two months regularly doing this yoga kiss, for the first time I could do two challenging poses successfully: chaturanga and full forward fold. I realize that the less pressure I give to myself, the better I feel with the flow.
I always have this one as my most favourite.
Thank you, Adriene, for your kindness to share the energy, the passion and the positive vibes.
Hugs,

Hi! In general, most women are able to continue a regular practice through month eight if they avoid twists below the neck, core activation and anything on the belly. Most will find they will know when something isn't right. Hip openers are good but go easier in third trimester. Modify core breaks with reclined cobbler's pose, modify belly stuff with child's pose or yogi's squat and modify standing twists with wide-legged forward fold. 

As always, consult your doctor/physician before starting and follow their advice. x
